conclusion: To determine the volume of the irregularly shaped solid using the device shown in the figure, follow these steps.
Position the Solid: Place the irregularly shaped solid (B) into the U-shaped tube.
Initial Measurement: Ensure the U-tube is in equilibrium with the mercury levels on both sides equal. This means there is no net pressure difference between the two sides.
Add Mercury to One Side: Slowly add mercury to one side (let's say the right side) of the U-tube until the mercury level on the other side rises due to the added weight.
Measure the Volume Change: Observe the change in the mercury level on the right side. Let’s assume the mercury level rises by h cm when you add a certain volume of mercury.

premise: The volume of mercury added can be calculated using the formula for the volume of a cylinder.
conclusion: Volume of Mercury Added: V_mercury = A × h where A is the cross-sectional area of the U-tube and h is the height difference in centimeters.

premise: The volume of mercury added is directly proportional to the volume of the solid displaced.
conclusion: Relate Mercury Volume to Solid Volume: V_solid = V_mercury

premise: The volume of the irregularly shaped solid can be determined by measuring the volume of mercury added to the U-tube when the solid is placed inside it.
conclusion: The volume of mercury added will be equal to the volume of the solid.
